article.title: The ALMA View of the OMC1 Explosion in Orion

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the image in Figure 1 primarily show?
choices: The locations of the BN object, Source I, Source n, and IRc4 in OMC1.
The proper motions of various stars within the Orion Nebula Cluster.
The high-velocity 230 GHz CO emission from the explosive OMC1 outflow.
The distribution of dust and gas within the Orion Molecular Cloud.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dashed circle in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The location of the Orion Nebula.
A region containing most of the high-velocity CO emission.
The projected orbit of the BN object around Source I.
The extent of the shock front caused by the OMC1 explosion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the color scheme in Figure 4 represent?
choices: Red shows blueshifted emission, blue shows redshifted emission.
Red shows high-density regions, blue shows low-density regions.
Blue shows blueshifted emission, red shows redshifted emission.
Blue shows older emission, red shows younger emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of velocity structure do the streamers in Figure 5 exhibit?
choices: Exponential velocity gradients.
Large-amplitude, linear velocity gradients.
Constant velocity across their length.
Oscillating velocity patterns.
The luminosity and mass of the stars involved in the OMC1 explosion.
The age and velocity of the OMC1 outflow.
The locations and radial velocities of the highest velocity CO knots in Orion OMC1.
The properties of the surrounding Orion A molecular cloud.
